segments.en: Linked Discourses 3
2. Childless
11. Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bahidvārakoṭṭhake nisinno hoti.
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and sat outside the gate.

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena satta ca jaṭilā satta ca nigaṇṭhā satta ca acelakā satta ca ekasāṭakā satta ca paribbājakā parūḷhakacchanakhalomā khārivividhamādāya bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
segments.en: Now at that time seven matted-hair ascetics, seven Jain ascetics, seven naked ascetics, seven one-cloth ascetics, and seven wanderers passed by not far from the Buddha. Their armpits and bodies were hairy, and their nails were long; and they carried their stuff with shoulder-poles.

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena te satta ca jaṭilā satta ca nigaṇṭhā satta ca acelakā satta ca ekasāṭakā satta ca paribbājakā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ nāmaṃ sāvesi:
segments.en: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward those various ascetics, and pronounced his name three times:

segments.pli: “rājāhaṃ, bhante, pasenadi kosalo … pe … rājāhaṃ, bhante, pasenadi kosalo”ti.
segments.en: “Sirs, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala! … I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo acirapakkantesu tesu sattasu ca jaṭilesu sattasu ca nigaṇṭhesu sattasu ca acelakesu sattasu ca ekasāṭakesu sattasu ca paribbājakesu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then, soon after those ascetics had left, King Pasenadi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

segments.pli: “ye te, bhante, loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā ete tesaṃ aññatarā”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, are they among those in the world who are perfected ones or who have entered the path to perfection?”

segments.pli: “Dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, tayā gihinā kāmabhoginā puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantena kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhontena mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhārayantena jātarūparajataṃ sādiyantena: ‘ime vā arahanto, ime vā arahattamaggaṃ samāpannā’ti.
segments.en: “Great king, as a layman enjoying sensual pleasures, living at home with your children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, perfumes, and makeup, and accepting gold and money, it’s hard for you to know who is perfected or on the path to perfection.
You can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them.

segments.pli: Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
segments.en: But only after a long time, not casually;
only when paying attention, not when inattentive;
and only by the wise, not the witless.
You can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …

segments.pli: Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;

segments.en: You can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …

segments.pli: So ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;

segments.en: You can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion.

segments.pli: Sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
segments.en: But only after a long time, not casually;
only when paying attention, not when inattentive;
and only by the wise, not the witless.”
“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing,
how well said this was by Master Gotama. …

segments.pli: ‘dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, tayā gihinā kāmabhoginā puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantena kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhontena mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhārayantena jātarūparajataṃ sādiyantena:
“ime vā arahanto, ime vā arahattamaggaṃ samāpannā”ti.
Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
So ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
Sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ;
Ete, bhante, mama purisā carā ocarakā janapadaṃ ocaritvā āgacchanti.
segments.en: Sir, these are my spies, my undercover agents returning after spying on the country.

segments.pli: Tehi paṭhamaṃ ociṇṇaṃ ahaṃ pacchā osāpayissāmi.
segments.en: First they go undercover, then I have them report to me.

segments.pli: Idāni te, bhante, taṃ rajojallaṃ pavāhetvā sunhātā suvilittā kappitakesamassū odātavatthā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricāressantī”ti.
segments.en: And now—when they have washed off the dust and dirt, and are nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, and dressed in white—they will amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
segments.en: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
“It’s not easy to know a man by his appearance.
You shouldn’t trust them at first sight.
For undisciplined men live in this world
disguised as the disciplined.
Like a fake earring made of clay,
like a copper halfpenny coated with gold,
they live hidden in the world,
corrupt inside but impressive outside.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī…

suttaplex.blurb: A diverse group of ascetics passes by, and Pasenadi asks the Buddha if any of them are perfected ones. The Buddha says it is not easy for one such as Pasenadi to judge the spiritual achievements of others. Pasenadi reveals that the men are, in fact, his spies.
